channel.title: pumping lemma on Notes
channel.description: Recent content in pumping lemma on Notes

item.title: CS135-lecture-20210209
item.description: How to show what a finite atomata can’t do # Pumping Lemma for regular languages # Let \(M\) be a DFA with \(p\) states. Let \(s \in L(M)\) , and \(|s| \geq p\) , “the length of \(s\) is greater than or equal to the number of states.” At one point we reach a state that is going to be visited twice first, we can call this “the first state that gets repeated.

item.title: CS135-lecture-20210217
item.description: Example proofs for pumping lemma # 1 # Let \(L\) be the set of all strings with an equal number of 0 and 1 over the alphabet {0,1}. i.e. { \(\lambda\) , 01, 10, 0011, 0101, 0110, 1001 …} Theorem: \(L\) is not regular. Proof: For purposes of contradicition assume \(L\) is regular. Because \(L\) is regular there must be a pumping length \(p\) .

item.title: CS135-lecture-20210318
item.description: Pumping lemma for CFL # PL for RL Given \( RL, L \) there exists \( p \) such that if \( w \in L \) and \( |w| \geq p \) then there exists \( w = xyz \) where \( |y| > 0 \) \( |xy| \leq p \) \( xy^iz \in L \) We consume \( w \) and we get to a state that is the first repeated state.

item.title: CS135-lecture-20210329
item.description: CFG to PDA algorithm # Starting from a CFG and going to a PDA is a lot easier than going the other way. Lets start out with this grammar: \( S \to AB \\ A \to aA \mid \lambda \\ B \to bB \mid \lambda\) We can start our PDA by drawing 3 states, one start and one accept. The first transition triple is \( \lambda, \empty, S \empty \) , and the second transition is \( \lambda, \empty, \empty \) .
